docs.lead_paragraph: NATIONAL An article on Monday about laws passed in the last year in six states to ban abortion after 20 weeks of pregnancy misspelled the surname of the president of the Center for Reproductive Rights. It is Nancy Northup, not Northrup.
docs.snippet: NATIONAL     An article on Monday about laws passed in the last year in six states to ban abortion after 20 weeks of pregnancy misspelled the surname of the president of the Center for Reproductive Rights.  It is Nancy Northup, not Northrup.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline.main: Born to Lose: Health Inequality at Birth

docs.abstract: Low birth weight, long recognized as an indicator of vulnerability to health problems, is also an indicator of poor economic prospects, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Low birth weight, long recognized as an indicator of vulnerability to health problems, is also an indicator of poor economic prospects, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the theory that fetuses can feel pain after 20 weeks (an idea disputed by mainstream medicine), several states have banned abortions later than this.

headline.seo: New Laws in Several States Restrict Later-Term Abortions
headline.main: Several States Forbid Abortion After 20 Weeks
headline.sub: New Laws Upend Basic Tenet of Current Rules: Viability;
headline.print_headline: New Laws in 6 States Ban Abortions After 20 Weeks

docs.snippet: On the theory that fetuses can feel pain after 20 weeks (an idea disputed by mainstream medicine), several states have banned abortions later than this.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dozens of new restrictions passed by states this year have chipped away at the right to abortion by requiring women to view ultrasounds, imposing waiting periods or cutting funds for clinics. But a new kind of law has gone beyond such restrictions, striking at the foundation of the abortion rules set out by the Supreme Court over the last four decades. These laws, passed in six states in little more than a year, ban abortions at the 20th week after conception, based on the theory that the fetus can feel pain at that point -- a notion disputed by mainstream medical organizations in the United States and Britain. Opponents of abortion say they expect that discussion of fetal pain -- even in the face of scientific criticism -- will alter public perception of abortion, and they have made support for the new laws a litmus test for Republicans seeking the presidency.

headline.main: New Laws in 6 States Ban Abortions After 20 Weeks

docs.abstract: Six states have passed laws in 2011 that ban abortions at the 20th week after conception, striking at foundation of abortion rules set out by Supreme Court over last four decades; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kara Goucher’s quick return to track competition after having a child is these days becoming the rule, rather than the exception.

headline.seo: Some Track Athletes Join Other Parents on the Run
headline.main: Some Runners Choose Not to Wait for a Family
headline.print_headline: Some Runners Choose Not to Wait for a Family

docs.abstract: Elite distance runner Kara Goucher, who took second place in the 10,000 meters at the USA Track and Field Championships, is one of a handful of athletes who have decided to compete and be mothers.
docs.snippet: Kara Goucher’s quick return to track competition after having a child is these days becoming the rule, rather than the exception.
